visibility_factors: moderate to heavy rain/sleet late afternoon and evening

alert_summary.description: Low chance of a snow/ice day. Temps hover 31–37°F with no accumulating snow; precipitation mainly rain with some light sleet after school hours. Roads may be wet and slushy but generally passable for a Michigan district.

Heavier rain and light sleet 3–8 PM with temps in the mid‑30s and gusts to mid‑20s mph could cause slick spots on elevated/untreated surfaces and reduced comfort on the commute home, but not a widespread shutdown scenario.

meteorology.overall_conditions_summary:
For Rockford, MI on Tuesday, January 13, 2026, temperatures run very close to freezing overnight (around 31°F) but rise into the mid‑30s (34–37°F) during the day. That gives roughly 8–10 hours below or right at 32°F in the pre‑dawn and early morning window, then a steady warming trend by late morning and afternoon.

Precipitation: The main steady precipitation waits until mid‑afternoon and evening. Forecast guidance shows 0.25" of liquid, falling primarily as rain with a transition to light sleet 5–7 PM, after the typical school dismissal window. Model output gives essentially 0" of accumulating snow, and any sleet appears light and short‑lived. This is not a classic Michigan snow‑day setup (no 4–6"+ snow, no pre‑dawn heavy bursts).

Wind/visibility: Winds gust into the low‑ to mid‑20s mph range from the SSW–WSW, adding some bite to the cold, especially at the bus stop, but remaining below typical wind‑closure thresholds. Visibility holds near 6 miles; only mist and rain reduce it slightly. No dense fog or whiteout‑style snow is indicated.

Timing vs. school operations: Overnight and morning hours (midnight–8 AM) are dry, just overcast/misty with temps right around 31–32°F. That supports mainly dry or just damp roads for the morning commute, with perhaps a few slick patches on untreated surfaces but nothing regionally crippling. The more impactful weather—moderate rain, then some light sleet—moves in mid‑ to late afternoon, after buses have run and roads have been treated by daytime crews. Because Michigan districts are accustomed to winter driving and the event is liquid‑dominant, this pattern does not strongly support canceling school.

Bottom line: Expect a raw, cloudy day with increasing wind and rain by afternoon and some mixed sleet in the early evening. From a snow‑day standpoint, hazards are below the usual closure threshold in West Michigan: low snow totals, marginal temperatures, no significant ice accretion signal, and the worst of the precipitation holding off until after the school day. Overall likelihood of a full snow/ice day is low, with normal operations or, at most, some caution advised for the late‑day commute.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Mid-January warm sector with temps near freezing, overcast, then afternoon/evening rain changing to light sleet, winds 15–25 mph, no accumulating snow
Wet, raw day with 0.25–0.50" liquid precipitation but surface temps 31–37°F and no significant icing on roads
Gusty, damp day with wind chills in the 20s but actual temps well above typical extreme-cold closure thresholds

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: For mid-January in west-central Lower Michigan (Rockford/GR corridor), it is common to see a mix of true winter days (lake-effect snow, highs in the 20s) interspersed with brief thaws where temperatures nudge above freezing and precipitation falls mainly as rain or a rain/snow mix. School closures in this region for this time of year are most frequently tied to: (1) overnight/early-morning snow bursts that quickly lay down several inches, (2) significant freezing rain or ice glaze events, or (3) arctic outbreaks with wind chills below about -15°F. A day that is predominantly above freezing with plain rain and no accumulating snow typically does not lead to closures.
unusual_factors: Temperatures are slightly above the climatological mid-January average much of the day (around 32–37°F vs. more typical mid/upper 20s for highs).
Precipitation type is mainly rain, with only a brief window of light sleet indicated late afternoon into early evening, and no modeled snow accumulation.
Winds are breezy (gusts into the 30–40 mph range) but below typical damaging-wind criteria, and there are no winter weather alerts in the provided data.

local_microclimates: Rockford is slightly north of Grand Rapids with some local elevation and proximity to the Rogue River, but its winter closure behavior tends to mirror the broader Kent County/Grand Rapids metro: systems that produce rain here usually mean even less winter impact south/west toward GR, and lake-effect snow bands that sometimes hit harder north or west are not present in this forecast.

Typical impactful events in this area in January are: strong clipper systems with lake-effect and blowing snow, or ice storms when warm air overruns a cold surface. Neither of those signatures is present in these hourly fields.
infrastructure_considerations: Road crews in Kent County are well-equipped for winter storms and handle light sleet and cold rain without major disruption, especially when pavement temps hover near freezing or above.

School transportation here is accustomed to operating with wet roads, wind chills in the 20s, and marginal wintry mix as long as there is not a flash-freeze or ice storm. Bus safety thresholds are far below the forecast wind chills and precipitation rates shown.
There are no alerts in the forecast data (no Winter Weather Advisory, Ice Storm Warning, or Wind Chill Advisory), which historically correlate much more strongly with closure or delay days.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Rockford’s modestly higher terrain relative to downtown Grand Rapids can occasionally favor slightly more snow in marginal setups, but in this case modeled precip type is predominantly rain with surface temps at or above freezing; that pattern does not usually translate into hidden snow/ice at local high spots—more of a cold, wet pavement scenario.

history.confidence_assessment:
Overall, this pattern historically produces an extremely low likelihood of a snow day in Rockford, Michigan. For Tuesday, 2026-01-13, temperatures stay near or above freezing (around 31–37°F), with no accumulating snow and only light sleet late day. Winds, while breezy, are not damaging, and wind chills remain in the 20s—nowhere near the roughly -15°F wind-chill threshold that has prompted cold-related closures in the region. Total liquid precipitation (~0.25"), timing (heavier rain/sleet after typical school dismissal), and lack of any ice accretion signal all argue against major travel disruption during the morning commute and school hours.

When comparing this to past mid-January events in west Michigan, this looks like a classic “raw, rainy, maybe briefly slushy” day rather than a snow day setup. Historically, days with similar profiles—temps hugging freezing but slightly above, plain rain dominant, no snow accumulation, no winter weather alerts—almost always see schools operate on a normal schedule. Adjusting for the time of year and local decision habits, the implied snow-day probability for Rockford Public Schools under a forecast like this is very low (on the order of a few percent or less), and much closer to a typical in-session winter day than to known closure scenarios driven by blizzards, ice storms, or dangerous arctic cold.

safety_recommendations: Proceed with normal in-person school operations; no snow day warranted based on current forecast.
Monitor for localized slick spots on untreated secondary roads and shaded areas, especially early morning when temps are near 31°F with mist and very high humidity.
Have plow/salt crews spot-treat bridges, overpasses, and campus entrances/parking lots before 6:00–7:00 AM due to temperatures hovering around freezing.
Alert bus drivers to potential patchy black ice and reduced contrast/visibility from mist and overcast skies during the 6:00–8:00 AM window.
Plan for wet road conditions and ponding during dismissal (after ~3 PM) as heavy rain and later sleet move in; emphasize slower speeds and longer stopping distances.
Ensure students and staff use appropriate footwear and caution on wet/slick sidewalks and parking lots, particularly at afternoon pick-up when rain intensifies.
Reassess conditions Tuesday afternoon/evening for any impact on after-school activities as heavy rain/sleet and gusty winds develop, but this does not affect morning school start.

local_news.headline: Rockford, MI forecast for Tuesday, Jan 13, 2026: light icy mix late, overcast
local_news.summary: Forecast for Rockford on Tuesday, Jan 13 shows highs around 39°F and lows near 33°F with an overcast sky and a light icy mix developing later in the day. Precipitation is relatively modest (~0.22"), with no indication of a major snowstorm or blizzard-level conditions. Roads could become slick late in the day but this is not the kind of high‑impact storm that automatically forces widespread closures by itself.

local_news.headline: Recent Winter Weather Advisory north/west of Kent County, but advisory window has passed
local_news.summary: A Winter Weather Advisory from NWS Grand Rapids covered portions of central and west‑central Michigan (Mason, Lake, Osceola, Oceana, Newaygo, Mecosta, Muskegon) through Sunday, Jan 11, for snow and gusty winds. The advisory has expired and did not target Kent County directly, though it indicates an active wintry pattern in the region. No new advisory or warning is posted in this feed for Kent County for Jan 12–13 as of now.

local_news.headline: West Michigan closings infrastructure active; no specific Rockford Jan 13 closure list yet
local_news.summary: WZZM 13 maintains a dedicated school closings page for West Michigan districts. The current page describes how to check if schools are closed but does not yet list Rockford Public Schools (MI) or Kent‑area districts as closed for Tuesday, Jan 13. When significant ice or snow is forecast, this list usually fills up the evening before or early morning of the affected day, but at this time there is no published Jan 13‑specific closings list focused on Kent County/Grand Rapids metro.

local_news.headline: Recent West Michigan closures due to icy roads and fog (not Jan 13‑specific)
local_news.summary: A recent WZZM 13 article reported that icy conditions and dense fog led to nearly two dozen West Michigan school closures on a prior Wednesday. This shows that local superintendents will close or delay school for non‑snow hazards like ice and visibility, but that event was a different date and weather setup than the forecast for Tuesday, Jan 13.

local_news.headline: Closings list for Jan 12–13 shows no entries for Jan 13 yet
local_news.summary: A generic school and business closings site shows “No Closings or Delays for January 13, 2026” in its nationwide feed. This site is not Kent‑specific but is another indication that, as of Monday, Jan 12 mid‑day, there are no widespread advance closure decisions for Tuesday being reported in public aggregators.

news.key_findings_summary:
As of Monday, January 12, 2026, mid‑day, there are **no public announcements or strong signals** pointing toward Rockford Public Schools (Michigan) or nearby Kent County districts closing for **Tuesday, January 13, 2026**.

Weather: Forecast data for Rockford on Tuesday, Jan 13 calls for **overcast conditions with a light icy mix developing later in the day**, highs around the upper 30s and lows in the low 30s. This suggests **marginal winter conditions**—slick roads are possible, especially later, but there is **no indication of a major snowstorm, blizzard, or extreme cold event** that would reliably trigger widespread pre‑announced closures.

Advisories/alerts: Recent **Winter Weather Advisories** from NWS Gaylord and NWS Grand Rapids targeted counties north and northwest of Kent and were in effect mainly through Sunday, Jan 11; they have **expired** and do not currently include Kent County for Jan 12–13.

District and neighbor signals: Public‑facing pages for Kent ISD‑area districts (including Lowell) and regional news feeds currently show **normal operations** and forward‑looking calendar items, without mention of weather‑related remote days, early dismissals, or Jan 13 closure planning. There are **no published closure lists or domino‑effect patterns** from Grand Rapids‑area neighbors for Jan 13 at this time.

Community chatter & outages: Within the public web and news footprint checked (local media, district sites, regional context), there is **no notable social media or community chatter** specifically discussing Rockford, MI, road hazards, power outages, or anticipated snow days for Tuesday. No Consumers‑style outage reports or local event cancellations tied to weather on Jan 13 have surfaced.

Overall, current open‑source signals support the idea that **Rockford Public Schools and surrounding districts are more likely than not to have school as usual on Tuesday, January 13, 2026**, unless the forecast deteriorates (especially if the icy mix timeline shifts earlier or intensifies) or new NWS advisories are issued later on Jan 12. Re‑checking local TV closings lists (WOOD TV8, WZZM 13, Fox 17), Kent ISD alerts, and Rockford Public Schools’ official channels this evening and early Tuesday morning will give the most accurate last‑minute picture.

primary_factors: No accumulating snow forecast (0"; precip mainly rain with brief light sleet late day)
Temperatures near/above freezing during commute windows (around 31–34°F) with a rising trend
Worst conditions (moderate rain/sleet) timed 3–7 PM, after morning bus runs and well into/after the school day
Historical analogs for this pattern show ~2–3% closure rate in west Michigan
Safety analyst explicitly recommends normal in-person operations; only moderate, localized slick-spot risk
No winter weather advisories for Kent County for Jan 13; prior advisories elsewhere have expired
News/closings pages show no Rockford or neighboring district closures and no community buzz about a snow day
final.decision_rationale:
1. Expert agreement and conflict check
- Meteorology: Indicates a low chance of closure. Temps hover around freezing overnight, rise into mid-30s, with ~0" snow and mainly rain. Morning (midnight–8 AM) is dry/overcast with maybe mist; heavier rain/light sleet comes 3–8 PM. Bottom line: not a snow-day setup.
- History: Strongly reinforces that this pattern almost never leads to closures (2–3% historical snow-day rate) in Rockford/GR: rain-dominant, marginal temps, no alerts, no arctic cold. Calls it a classic “raw, rainy, maybe briefly slushy” school day.
- Safety: Rates primary roads 8/10, secondaries and lots 7/10; morning commute impact minimal, afternoon moderate. Recommends normal in‑person school, with targeted salting and caution for slick spots and wet roads.
- News/Community Intel: No advisories for Kent County for Jan 13, no Rockford/neighbor closures listed, no social-media buzz, and generic closings pages show no Jan 13 entries. Local forecast language describes a light icy mix later in the day, not a storm-level event.

All four experts agree: (a) this is not a significant snow or ice storm, (b) morning conditions are generally fine for school, and (c) the higher-impact weather is later in the day. There are no substantive conflicts—only nuance about a "moderate" but localized ice formation risk.

2. Plow timing math
- Snow/ice accumulation: Models show essentially 0" snow and no meaningful ice accretion; risk is mainly brief slickness from marginal temps and wet surfaces.
- Timing: Roads are mainly dry/damp overnight into the morning. Any mist or patchy black ice risk is around the 6–8 AM window but not widespread.
- Buses start ~6–7 AM; school start ~7:30–8:00 AM. The more intense precip (heavier rain, then light sleet) ramps up around 3 PM and continues to ~7 PM.
- That leaves essentially unlimited time between the end of anything marginally icy and the morning commute, and the worst conditions come after dismissal when crews can actively treat surfaces. This is not a case where plows need hours to clear 4–8" of snow; instead it is standard winter wet-road management.

3. Ice considerations
- Temperatures: around 31°F early, then into the mid‑30s. That supports possible spotty slickness on bridges, untreated secondary roads, and shaded lots pre‑dawn, but a warming trend reduces risk as the morning progresses.
- Precip type: "Mixed" overall, but specifically rain-dominant with a short light sleet window late afternoon/early evening. No modeled ice accretion and no freezing rain signature.
- Safety analyst: Flags ice formation risk as "moderate" but still recommends normal school with targeted salting and bus driver awareness. That indicates nuisance to moderate slick spots, not system-wide hazardous ice.

Given that Michigan thresholds treat 8+" or true icing as a 60–85% closure setup, the complete absence of accumulating snow and of a true freezing-rain event keeps this day far below typical closure criteria.

4. Neighboring districts and news intel
- Neighboring district closures list: Empty for Jan 13; no entries in closings aggregators, no Rockford or Kent ISD‑area neighbors calling off.
- NWS and local TV: No current winter weather advisory/warning for Kent County for Jan 13.
- Community sentiment: "no_buzz"—people are not talking about a snow day or major storm.

Per the weighting rules, News Intel is a key factor: if neighbors were closing, we would add 15–20% to the probability, but we have the opposite: zero signals of closure. This strongly supports staying near the low end of the Michigan threshold ranges.

5. Weighting of experts (explicit)
- Meteorology (35% weight): Strongly points to non-event for closures (low hazard in pre‑dawn, worse weather later). If taken alone, this suggests perhaps ~5–10% closure probability, driven only by low‑probability surprise icing.
- Safety (25%): Rates conditions as safe enough for normal operations with precautions. Implied closure chance around ~5–10%—only if ice is worse than expected.
- History (20%): Past analogs show ~2–3% closure rate. This pulls the blended probability down toward the very low single digits.
- News Intel (20%): No neighboring closures, no advisories, no chatter. This behaves like a strong negative signal, keeping us near the historical baseline rather than bumping us up the way active closure lists would.

Blending these: 
- Meteorology: ~8% * 0.35 ≈ 2.8
- Safety: ~8% * 0.25 ≈ 2.0
- History: ~3% * 0.20 ≈ 0.6
- News Intel: ~5% * 0.20 ≈ 1.0
Sum ≈ 6.4%, rounded to a decisive 7% to acknowledge small upside risk from an unexpected earlier or stronger icy mix.

6. Why not higher (e.g., 15–30%)?
- Michigan closure thresholds emphasize significant snow totals (4–6"+) or ice/blizzard-level impacts. We have 0" snow and no ice storm.
- No winter weather alerts, no neighboring closures, and normal historical behavior in such setups argue strongly against anything in the moderate-probability range.
- The plow/salt demands are routine; infrastructure is built for this.

7. What would make this prediction wrong?
Key failure modes:
- The light icy mix arrives **several hours earlier** than forecast, creating widespread freezing rain or significant sleet accumulation starting before 5–6 AM rather than mid/late afternoon.
- Surface temperatures run **1–3°F colder** than forecast, causing a flash ice event even with modest QPF, especially if untreated roads glaze over.
- A late-day NWS advisory is issued for **freezing rain or significant ice accretion** centered on Kent County.
- A domino effect of closures develops among neighboring Kent ISD/GR metro districts tonight, signaling a risk perception shift not captured in current data.
Any of these would justify materially raising the probability into at least the 25–40% range or higher.

8. Final decision
Given strong multi-expert agreement, routine winter conditions for Michigan, low historical closure rates for this exact setup, and no peer-district closure signals, the best calibrated forecast is a **7% probability of a snow/ice day** for Rockford Public Schools on Tuesday, January 13, 2026. Normal school operations are expected, with attention to localized slick spots and a wetter, sloppier afternoon commute.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Forecast holds: mostly dry/misty morning around 31–32°F, roads mostly just damp; heavier rain and brief sleet 3–7 PM with temps in mid‑30s. No significant snow or ice accumulation.
alternative_scenarios.impact: Normal school day. Some slick patches possible early on untreated surfaces and wet/sloppy dismissal, but routine winter driving for Michigan. No need for closure or delay.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Marginally worse ice: temps hover at/just below freezing slightly longer and a bit more sleet/freezing drizzle occurs than forecast, including near or just before the morning commute.
alternative_scenarios.impact: Localized hazardous spots on secondary roads and bridges. Possible minor delays or very localized decisions (individual bus route adjustments), but still unlikely to cause district‑wide closure. Heightened need for pre‑treatment and driver caution.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Low‑probability bust: a band of freezing rain or heavier sleet develops over Kent County earlier than expected, creating widespread glazing by early morning.
alternative_scenarios.impact: Travel significantly degraded with broad ice coverage. Under this scenario, a last‑minute closure or delay becomes plausible, and after‑school activities could be curtailed. This is the main tail‑risk that our 7% overall probability is accounting for.

for_schools: Plan for normal in-person operations on Tuesday, Jan 13, 2026; do not preemptively call a snow/ice day based on current data.
Schedule salt/maintenance crews to spot-treat bridges, overpasses, campus entrances, and main parking lot lanes before 6:00–7:00 AM due to temps near freezing and potential patchy slick spots.
Communicate to bus drivers to watch for isolated black ice and low-contrast visibility in mist/overcast during the 6:00–8:00 AM window; emphasize conservative speeds on secondary and rural routes.
Prepare for a wet, potentially ponding dismissal period from ~3–5 PM; remind staff and families to allow extra stopping distance and use caution in pickup/drop-off loops.

Monitor NWS Grand Rapids updates and local TV/radio closings lists this evening and early morning for any unexpected issuance of freezing-rain advisories or evidence the icy mix is trending earlier/stronger.

Consider reviewing after-school activity plans day-of; be ready to cancel or adjust evening events if rain/sleet intensify and winds pick up after 3 PM, even though this does not justify a morning closure.
for_residents: Expect school to be in session; plan morning routines as normal but allow a little extra time for the drive in case of isolated slick spots.
Use caution early Tuesday on bridges, overpasses, and untreated neighborhood streets where temps near 31°F and high humidity could cause patchy black ice.
Ensure children have waterproof footwear and appropriate outerwear for a cold, damp day and a wet afternoon pickup.
For teen drivers, remind them to slow down on wet roads during dismissal and early evening, especially as rain intensifies and visibility decreases.

If conditions seem icier than forecast early in the morning (glazing on cars/driveways), check official school channels and local TV/radio for any last-minute changes, but baseline expectation is normal operations.
for_authorities: Have county and municipal crews prioritize anti-icing/spot salting of known trouble spots (bridges, hills, shaded curves) before the morning commute, especially 4–7 AM.
Maintain normal winter operations staffing through the afternoon as heavier rain and some sleet develop, focusing on drainage to prevent ponding and maintaining good friction on major routes.

Continue close coordination between road commissions and school transportation offices for real-time updates on any unexpectedly slick corridors, especially in higher or more rural parts of the district.

Monitor short-term forecasts and radar nowcasting overnight for any signal of earlier or more widespread freezing precipitation; be prepared to escalate treatment if surface temps underperform the forecast by a few degrees.

No need at this time for special emergency posture (warming centers or widespread travel advisories), but standard winter travel advisories and public messaging on slower speeds and increased following distances are appropriate for the afternoon/evening period.
